components/esm/loadgmst.hpp

Go to the documentation of this file.
00001 #ifndef _ESM_GMST_H
00002 #define _ESM_GMST_H
00003 
00004 #include "esm_reader.hpp"
00005 #include "defs.hpp"
00006 
00007 namespace ESM
00008 {
00009 
00010 /*
00011  *  Game setting, with automatic cleaning of "dirty" entries.
00012  *
00013  */
00014 
00015 struct GameSetting
00016 {
00017     std::string id;
00018 
00019     // One of these is used depending on the variable type
00020     std::string str;
00021     int i;
00022     float f;
00023     VarType type;
00024 
00025     // Set to true if this is a 'dirty' entry which should be ignored
00026     bool dirty;
00027 
00028     /*
00029      These functions check if this game setting is one of the "dirty"
00030      GMST records found in many mods. These are due to a serious bug in
00031      the official TES3 editor. It only occurs in the newer editor
00032      versions that came with Tribunal and Bloodmoon, and only if a
00033      modder tries to make a mod without loading the corresponding
00034      expansion master file. For example, if you have Tribunal installed
00035      and try to make a mod without loading Tribunal.esm, the editor
00036      will insert these GMST records as a replacement for the entries it
00037      cannot find in the ESMs.
00038 
00039      The values of these "dirty" records differ in general from their
00040      values as defined in Tribunal.esm and Bloodmoon.esm, and are
00041      always set to the same "default" values. Most of these values are
00042      nonsensical, ie. changing the "Seller Max" string to "Max Sale",
00043      or change the stats of werewolves to useless values like 1. Some
00044      of them break certain spell effects.
00045 
00046      It is most likely that these values are just leftover values from
00047      an early stage of development that are inserted as default values
00048      by the editor code. They are supposed to be overridden when the
00049      correct esm file is loaded. When it isn't loaded however, you get
00050      stuck with the initial value, and this gets written to every mod
00051      by the editor, for some reason.
00052 
00053      Bethesda themselves have fallen for this bug. If you install both
00054      Tribunal and Bloodmoon, the updated Tribunal.esm will contain the
00055      dirty GMST settings from Bloodmoon, and Bloodmoon.esm will contain
00056      some of the dirty settings from Tribunal. In other words, this bug
00057      affects the game EVEN IF YOU DO NOT USE ANY MODS!
00058 
00059      The guys at Bethesda are well aware of this bug (and many others),
00060      as the mod community and fan base complained about them for a long
00061      time. But unfortunately it was never fixed.
00062 
00063      There are several tools available to help modders remove these
00064      records from their files, but not all modders use them, and they
00065      really shouldn't have to. In this file we choose instead to reject
00066      all the corrupt values at load time.
00067 
00068      These functions checks if the current game setting is one of the
00069      "dirty" ones as described above. TODO: I have not checked this
00070      against other sources yet, do that later. Currently recognizes 22
00071      values for tribunal and 50 for bloodmoon. Legitimate GMSTs in mods
00072      (setting values other than the default "dirty" ones) are not
00073      affected and will work correctly.
00074      */
00075 
00076     /*
00077      Checks for dirty tribunal values. These will be ignored if found
00078      in any file except when they are found in "Tribunal.esm".
00079      */
00080     bool isDirtyTribunal();
00081 
00082     // Bloodmoon variant
00083     bool isDirtyBloodmoon();
00084 
00085     void load(ESMReader &esm);
00086 };
00087 }
00088 #endif
